competitors.name: Sterling Commerce
competitors.notes: Major EDI and B2B integration provider with Gentran Integration Suite

competitors.name: GXS (Global Exchange Services)
competitors.notes: Leading EDI VAN and B2B integration network, originally from General Electric

competitors.name: Inovis
competitors.notes: EDI and B2B integration provider, active in VAN services

competitors.name: IBM EDI Services
competitors.notes: IBM's traditional EDI VAN services and Information Exchange business

competitors.name: Kleinschmidt
competitors.notes: EDI VAN provider serving retail and supply chain markets

competitors.name: DiCentral
competitors.notes: EDI services provider for retail and supply chain integration

context: In 2005, SPS Commerce launched the Retail Network, establishing its cloud-based trading partner community. The EDI market was dominated by traditional VAN (Value-Added Network) providers like Sterling Commerce, GXS, and Inovis. These companies were evolving from pure VAN services to 'integration service providers' offering software, services, and hosting. The EDI industry was experiencing 5-20% annual revenue declines as the market matured and consolidated.
